displayed_text: Family Member: But do you know right away after one or two? Doctor: I would say probably after two or three you’d know if it’s working. Family Member: By that time, would we be able to go to Germany within a month? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: All we’ve got is a maybe. Family Member: Can’t be sure? Doctor: Well, let me explore, so I’ve got a couple of threads I’ve got to explore a little more. Patient: Thank you. I appreciate that. Doctor: So let’s uh- Patient: So we’re off the trial now? Doctor: Yeah. We’re off the trial. We’ll probably just want to see a PSA in another month off the testosterone. That may be complicated because you may, because we’re working to go somewhere else so, it may not be that useful for us because it’s not like you’re going to be on- Healthcare Professional: Is it thirty days as before? In those terms I don’t know-

Patient: Uh, there’s no penalty if I don’t, is there? Doctor: If you don’t go on-? Patient: If I do go there and don’t go on it? Where, where will I get the shots at if I um stay here? Doctor: Here. Patient: Oh, here? Doctor: Yes. In the hospital. You just, uh, or downstairs in radiation, sorry. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. They have a room that, uh, where they would do the- Patient: You can’t tell what I’m getting? Doctor: No. No. I think we’ll, we will know if you’re getting the real thing or not. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But, you know, we don’t have a choice.

Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So, a lot of people are different in their activity level. You know, some folks are just go, go, go, and some are like Patient: RIght. Doctor: oh, no, I like to chill and be on my computer and watch my TV and get on the phone, you know, so everyone’s activity level. Patient: I like more activity. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and… Doctor: That’s what I’m thinking. Family Member: The tests should be back by then? Doctor: Yeah, but you know what just for now wait for a phone call and I’ll have S call you as soon as we get the results so we can sort of plan better for that Friday. Family Member: So it’s just a one day in and out thing? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Show me how is the shoulder doing? Patient: Oh the shoulders are good. Doctor: Okay what is…? Patient: I don’t have any you know… Doctor: Is this ten mg? Patient: Five in the morning, five at night. Doctor: Okay did it flare up after the treatment last time? Family Member: No.

Patient: Let me say this here, Doc. Let me say this here. Everything that you tell me and you do – Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: she goes and she looks up everything Doctor: Perfect. Yes. Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____. Family Member: It’s just what bothers me about it is the pain that sometimes he go through. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Sometimes the pain can be a ten and then sometimes the pain can be a four. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If he had a four, I’d be comfortable with him being on the bike – Doctor: Yeah, I know.

Patient: It passes freely. (Pause) Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I think I do. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I did take iron. I just had my, my hip redone. I had it replaced seven years ago, but it got loose. And they took it apart and put some – Doctor: When was that? Patient: February Doctor: But not since you last saw me? Patient: Oh, no. But I did take iron then, but I haven’t taken it since. So. Doctor: Have you been thinking clearly? Any issues with your – just how you process things? Patient: No. (Clicking) Doctor: Anything new on your body today? Rashes? Skin changes?

Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: So I will call you probably Friday- Patient: Okay. Doctor: With some information. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan.

Family Member: Xtandi, okay. Doctor: and then we’ll throw on a second medication. Patient: What are the names of the other two drugs? Doctor: No names. All letters and numbers. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Poof! You just turn into a guinea pig again. You were there before, but yeah. I think that’s the hard part. It’s umm, you know, they don’t give names unless it’s moving along the path of development. Umm. And then uh, it’s sorta like you don’t name your pet…you don’t think you’re gonna keep it. I don’t know. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: But, it’s usually letters and numbers. Ummm. But, they work in a class of drugs that we think are highly active in prostate cancer, so it’s about five different drugs that are in this space, targeting the same pathway. So, we just don’t know which one has an opening. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And, when would that start? Doctor: M___ will tell us, but probably, you know, obviously in the new year, and it maybe second or third week… Patient: Well, they took seven vials of blood…

Family Member: Why don’t we just stop it. Doctor: So go ahead and stop it for now. And we’ll restart it once we feel comfortable that there’s no bleeding and you know… Patient: Okay so I’m off the aspirin. Even the little ones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Totally off the aspirin. Healthcare Professional: Even the baby aspirin. Family Member: And that’s what B____ said. Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time.

Patient: What time would it be? Doctor: I don’t know. What time do you prefer? Family Member: Not Friday because you’re helping me with my health fair. Doctor: Fair enough. Patient: Uh how about um… Family Member: Thursday you’re seeing P in the morning. Patient: Yeah. Could we do it Thursday afternoon? Doctor: Sure, yeah. Family Member: It’s just an echo… Patient: How long does it take – to do that ? Doctor: It’s about, not a very long time, but it would mean that I would just need to, we would need to coordinate the echo appointment and all that- that’s why I’m just asking you for Patient: Thursday afternoon.

Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night. Doctor: So you’re waking up because of pain? Patient: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for? Doctor: Discomfort? Patient: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has? Family Member: The bean bag. Patient: The bean bags. That was the worst idea I ever had. When I got in that bean bag, uh, I, I was in pain. And the bad part is I couldn’t get back out of the, get out of the bean bag, and get off the floor.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Thursday afternoon. Doctor: -a few days. that work out well for you Because… Patient: Thursday afternoon. We’re going to Canada on Saturday morning. Doctor: Okay and then next week. Patient: Closer than Vancouver. Doctor: Fair enough. Next week anytime? Family Member: For the same thing? Patient: Are we giving you a couple alternatives? Doctor: Yeah give me a couple options. Patient: Thursday this week and uh… Family Member: Monday? Patient: No No Tuesday next week. Doctor: Tuesday, good. That works out because then Tuesday I’ll be there too if you have any questions about the consent if anything comes up. So we’ll try for this week Thursday or Tuesday next week.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You mentioned before that you were taking a number of supplements and you know, we're interested in natural products and how they may help your risk of cancer or cancer progression. Doctor: So, I think that that would be a reasonable first approach to see and hear. You know, first to see if you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then, get the genetic testing for the study. And then if you are, join that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I think that’s fair. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I think that’s reasonable. It reasonable. Doctor: Are you just agreeing with me to agree with me? Patient: No, no, no, no, no, no. Really.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Alright I was wondering if uh… Patient: How about the CAT scan? Doctor: CAT scan I just called them. Patient: Sure. Doctor: They’re still loading the images. So they said they’ll let me know in a few minutes once it’s ready. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay let me try and I’m going to… Patient: Take a look. Doctor: Did they put it in yet? Family Member: No. Doctor: Let me at least have it uploaded. Patient: Yeah.
